Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not cut from that [area of the body] except that which adds to the natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from that more, you will wound and damage the speech and the voice.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision use what we mentioned concerning the incision of two amygdals: and care for it until it heals
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the sickly one returns from the incision: then it is necessary that you use your skill in cauterization without fear and without haste
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the mode of cauterization in this is not except with acute water: and it is that you place the head of the sickly one in your palm.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument which we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I mentioned before in the chapter on cauterization, and mix with it burnt lime, and put it not thick, neither sparse, and press from it the concavity of this instrument
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	So that the extremities of it in which the medicine is placed is like the concavity of the radius of a spiral
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine upon that very thing: and the sickly one lies upon his side, so that the saliva runs out from his mouth from the intrinsic medicine, and does not descend from that to the gut of him anything, and harms him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first hour until midday you must stay by the patient, until the fever has departed, and give the medicine without delay.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a seat, place your hand on the outer side of the limb, apply the medicine to the limb, and insert the limb into the canula above, until the limb adheres to the limb above
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times until you observe that the pulse has ceased to be affected by the burn.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then depart from him: for he will himself rise and fall in three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you do not find that she is better when you return, return to her: and after the burn, remove from the circumference of the limb all that is moist with medicine, and dry with oil; and keep her cool with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	Care for the outside with bandages, and the inside with gargles, until she is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus is this kind of treatment safer than incision and longer lasting than fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the limb is healed even with the burn, it is better to treat it with fumes than by incision or burning: for it is healed by means of fumigation in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and chamomile, and wormwood, and saffron, and similar herbs: and mix them all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them in vinegar, and boil: and put the pot on a tripod in the middle of the pot.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make it from silver, or from brass: and insert the extremity, in which is the pomegranate seed, into the patient's bone, until the vapor reaches the limb above the canula, until the limb becomes very dark
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over the area several times until it swells.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	Do not perform this treatment at the onset of an abscess.</start_of_turn>
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Increase the heat in the abscess: do not perform this treatment until the abscess has cooled down.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If you do not have this instrument, take a willow branch and apply its bark to the extremity: so that it does not burn the sick bone: because the bark of the willow prevents the vapor from burning the bone: and this is from a good treatment with safety.</start_of_turn
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the extraction of thorns and bones from the jaw.</start_of_turn
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.</start_of_turn
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many thorns adhere to the jawbone, or fish bone, or something else.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore that you extract what is visible from the wound after you have put the tongue with the instrument at the angle of the jaw, and you declare that it is in the jaw.</start_of_turn
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what is not visible to you and is hidden in the jaw, you must make the patient vomit before it is digested in the stomach.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps the foreign body will come out with the vomit.</start_of_turn
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient may swallow a piece of chaff, or a radish, or a piece of dry bread, or take a sponge of dry seaweed: and bind it with a thread, and then swallow it.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it has reached the place where the thorns or bones are, and they are extracted, then they are ejected.</start_of_turn
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore he does not depart with me as we have said: then use the instrument of lead according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	If therefore he does not depart with me as we have said: then use the instrument of lead according to this shape. Let it be thicker than the Radius minor and have a curvature at its extremity, which intrudes into his guttur with ease: and let him have his head raised above.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And beware of his epiglottis, that it does not suffer from pain, and drive with him bone, or thorn, or introduce himself the physician his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Truly, that the patient intrudes: this is better: because of his science of the place of the annexed thing: and drives downwards, or pulls his hand upwards with the instrument, throughout all this according to the quantity that is prepared for him, until he departs
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Of the extraction of blood.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When he is treated for bleeding with that which I have said in the preceding discourse concerning the treatment with physicians, and it does not suffice, then consider in the guttur of the patient before his tongue, or behind the tongue after having grasped his tongue with the instrument which I have mentioned to you
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your hand slips from the bleeding, extract it with a small hook, or with fine fingers from the middle.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If this is not possible with the hook: then grasp a curved needle, and introduce it into the guttur of the patient almost up to the guttur: then introduce into the curvature of the needle a burning iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this often: and let the patient abstain from all water throughout the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then give him a full treatment of cold water, and open his mouth with it: and clench his jaw with it, and do not swallow anything from it: and let him drink water an hour after another with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The bleeding ceases when it feels water falling from it.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If it does not stop when the water is poured on it, then smother the diseased part with wool or with an instrument as I mentioned in the explanation of the sponge
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do it often, for it will stop bleeding by itself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	The method of operation in the application of the sponge is as follows: take a ball of cotton wool which has been boiled with urine and which has been made dry by fire: put the pot on the instrument and make a hole in the middle of it.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then pour the sponge onto the wound and hold the diseased part in the extremity of the instrument and clamp it so that the sponge does not escape until you know that the sponge has stopped the bleeding
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For bleeding stops immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not stop, repeat the application of the sponge often
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can sit still and eat garlic and onions, and does not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he go out like this.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	This is the way in which the bleeding is extracted from the gut when it falls onto the urine.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like tweezers, as with urine: except that it has this hardness which penetrates the gut
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the beak of a heron which is named ciconia, in which there is the hardness of lime: when it grasps something, it does not let go of it at all
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Of the opening of the rectum, and its cutting, and care in general
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many different kinds of abscesses, of various degrees, according to the recollection of their nature, namely one kind, and one of this kind in this book: and they differ in perforation and cutting from two modes.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One kind of abscess is that which originates from moisture.</start_of_turn>
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The other kind is that which arises from the body itself.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since abscesses arise in the head, they are different from those that arise in the belly: and an abscess that arises in a fleshy part is different from one that arises in a joint: each one of these has its own judgment based on its operation.</start_of_turn
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	There are also abscesses which do not require perforation, except after the passage of time and the completion of its complement: and there are those which require perforation while they are raw and have not matured, according to their complement.</start_of_turn
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	For example, abscesses which are close to joints.</start_of_turn
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	An abscess which arises near a joint and persists, may possibly corrupt the ligaments or nerves of that joint: this is the cause of the contraction of that limb.</start_of_turn>
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or an abscess which is near a principal limb: for if you delay its perforation until it matures, it will cause pain or swelling or both in that limb.</start_of_turn
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is close to an organ, perforate it immediately: it is not right to perforate an immature abscess, except if it is close to an organ, so that it does not putrefy deeply and reach the interior of the belly, and form a fistula, or remain unhealed.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of perforation of the apostemate, which has matured according to the complement: and it is among the sedation of pain, recession of fever, reduction of redness, and pulsation, and the acuteness of the apostemate of the head: and the other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary that you make the perforation in a lower place of the apostemate, and more cautiously: and let the perforation be wide in length of the body, if the apostemata are in the parts of the hands and feet, and in the places of lacerations, and strings, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places where there is no reflection
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which reflect, be cautious with the perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When indeed the aposmate is in carious places: then it is better that you delay the perforation of it until its digestion has been confirmed, as we said according to the complement
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, you prolong the course of the evil from it, and there is much pain and swelling, and perhaps the lips will swell up, and deepen its extent
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some apostemata are perforated according to the width of the body for necessity: or according to that which the limb requires
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you manage in small apostemata a moderate perforation, and in great apostemata a wide perforation: or many sections like the magnitude of the apostemate.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are some apostemata in which it is necessary to sew the skin: and this happens when it has been made like a piece of leather, and has been made at the end, which is dead: as happens in many things, as in wounds of the gut, and abscesses.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from bones there are those which are cut with section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from bones there are those which are cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the heel of the foot.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from bones there are those in which are administered round section and lunar section: and similar bones from sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	This, however, which has no head, like the superficial heel bones, must be perforated through a superficial perforation, or only plane
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it must be, when the heel is thick, and when it is united with much flesh, and you perforate it, that you do not break it and extract all the pus at once: rather extract from it a part of it
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then oil the heel until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this often according to the degrees, until it is expelled: especially if the patient is feeble of virtue, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man who is decrepit: for the spirit of the animal is dissolved with the expulsion of the matter: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not perceive it
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take heed of this chapter with great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated the bone, which you must perforate the heel bones, you must remove the clot: and consider
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a clot in the heel bones, or if it is a flat section, then administer ointment from liniment, or old fat
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the heel is large, and there are many wounds of perforation, then you must introduce into every wound ointment, until they reach the innermost part
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have excised a part of the skin in the apostemate, or if you have cauterized the circumference: then it is necessary to apply to the wound either fat or as it is wont when a bandage is taken off, or to spread over it a covering of wool without moisture: and to draw it tight until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	And draw it tight, and care for it as much as is necessary until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if there should be a flow of blood in your operation at the time: then give cold water and vinegar, after having swallowed in some sponge: and place it over the site of the flow of blood many times over.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flow of blood should persist: then it is necessary to administer treatment, care, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this book, and from experience.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the winter, and the site of the apostemate is of many nerves: then it is necessary to instill sponges with wine and warm fat: and place them over the place.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer, and the place is fleshy: then it is necessary to place sponges soaked in water and fat, or in wine and fat, and all of this cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must loosen the apostemate, and remove it, and administer to it what is suitable for it until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is what is necessary to know concerning the treatment of apostemata in general
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the manner of distinguishing things, as I have said of every apostemate, how it is necessary to treat each one separately
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Of the section of apostemata which happen in the head-skin.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	The head has small abscesses in its bones, which are of the kind of knots which contain tunics, which are like sacks: as if they were the breasts of a hen.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	There are many kinds of these knots
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	They are of many kinds: some contain fat, others moisture like mud, others moisture like blood and pus, and some like stones
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in their section and their extraction there is no fear, as long as one does not do violence to the arteries during their section.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	The operation for their section is to be learned with the instrument which has the form which follows these things, which is called the Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then dry it out by the superficial section: by this form
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin by making an incision from point b to point g. When the moisture has been evacuated, remove the knot which contains it, and do not leave anything behind
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	There will be many of them remaining, if anything is left behind
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the head in Egyptian unguent, if it is present: or in water and salt. And apply to it a willow twig, and keep it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The abscesses will be softened by this.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Repeat the operation on the head with Egyptian unguent three times, and if it does not improve, until you are confident that there is nothing remaining of the abscess. Then apply a bandage with unguent until it is healed
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the swelling continues to contain a pimple: then dry it out with this form, by cutting with a blade having the shape of a cross: and project the hooks between the two cuts, and scrape it clean from all sides: and strive with your skill in the extraction of the tunic which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it makes resistance, the artery has burst: then do that which I shall tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And in a swelling which contains a stone, do the same from the cut, and the treatment is the same as before.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	The cutting above a swelling which contains a stone is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some swellings of the head in some people, in which there is no moisture at all
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Because I have cut above a swelling of a woman's head, and I found a swelling like a solid stone, hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if I pierced it with anything, it wounded it.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other swellings of the head which occur, except for these which occur in the heads of children, and at the roots of the ears, the complete cut is a superficial cut
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation always from below upwards, so as to drive the blood downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it as suits the case.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Note: The provided text does not include any information regarding the section of the thyroid in the neck, so I cannot translate that section.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many swellings of the neck occur under the chin, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And above all that happens from the things which happen in the neck, there is one, and many: and they are generated from one. And every Strophula comes from the things themselves which are inside their own tunic, as in the nodes and the apostemata of the head, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the species of these Strophula are many.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from things there are soft: and from things there are which contain humors: and from things there are malignant, which do not obey treatment.</start_of_turn>
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	And concerning the things from which good humors arise in the touch, the manifestation of which is near the color of the skin, and which move to every part, and are not attached to the nerves of the neck, neither to the arteries, nor to the veins, nor is it deep: it must be cut away by a superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body from the line, be it from the line, or from below, and remove it from all sides: and spread out two lips of the skin with one finger, or with many fingers if necessary, as we said concerning the apostemata of the head, and remove it gradually.</start_of_turn>
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is important to be cautious that the bone, or the nerve, does not be injured.</start_of_turn
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the sponge be not too acute, so that it does not add its hand to the incision, or disturb the patient, and cut only what is necessary.</start_of_turn
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If however you cut a vein, or an artery, or if you are forbidden by the operation, then put in the wound a piece of sponge which has been well-soaked in powder which absorbs blood, and compress the wound, and hold it still until the bleeding has ceased: or until the swelling has gone down.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	Blood is severed by the clamp of Redi, until the operation is finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger whether anything remains from the other small trophues: if so, cut them away and wash them clean.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If there is in the root of the trophue a large bone: then it is necessary that you do not cut through that trophue from its root: but rather that you bind it with a strong doubled thread, and let it go until it falls off by itself without any suture
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then apply a sponge soaked in Egyptian unguent to the part which you have immersed in the unguent
Deinde cura ipsum.	Take care of yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the entire trophue is cut through, then it is necessary that you join together two lips of the wound: and hold them in place immediately, after you have washed because there remains no surplus.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If, however, you wash and find there remains surplus due to the size of the trophue, then it is necessary that you insert it to the cutting of its root and pull it out: and administer a suture as we have said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what remains of the trophues, keep it moistened with a perforation made with a superficial hole: so that you may see the place of its maturity: and put the perforation from that which follows below the body as we have said
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation a lint with unguent, and similar things, so that it may consume what remains of the corruption: until when you wash the wound will be healed: then take care of yourself with the unguent of the generation of flesh, until it is healed
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Regarding the section of the epiglottis from the epiglottis to the gullet by accident.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They say that in the Epiglottis of the ancients, no one in our land has made it: this is the writing of their discourse.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in other parts of the body, if the section of the Epiglottis be not delayed, it must be made: for if it be not done, all the veins and the lungs will be diseased.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a soft swelling in the mouth, or the gullet, or in two tonsils, when there is no inflammation in the channel, it is necessary to make a section of the Epiglottis in order to escape the destruction which results from its prolapse
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore, when we wish to do this, to cut through the Epiglottis under three or four circles of the Epiglottis, with a small section across the width, in the place where there is a section in cartilage, not in bone: and this place is convenient for the section, because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are long
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the gullet with a finger.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then grasp the skin, until it reaches the channel: there will be bleeding from it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut through the cartilage which we have mentioned: and it is signified by the escape of phlegm from it, when it is ruptured, and by the cutting of the mucous membrane.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And hold the wound open for a while.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the time has passed in which the prolapse is overcome, gather together the two lips of the wound in the skin, and close it alone without cartilage
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then give medicines which promote the healing of the flesh, until it is healed
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis said.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Albucasis said.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw with mine own eyes, that a handmaid took a knife and put it into her gut, and it went into a part of the pulmonary canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to care for her, and I found her to be dead like a corpse
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw that there was a wound, and I found blood which had escaped from the wound of the heel
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was doubtful that she would recover, neither would she guide me: and the wind was going out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I did well, and I bandaged her wound, and cared for her: and the handmaid did nothing else, except that she wept in the water: and she returned after a few days in better condition than before.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Hence it is said: there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Of the section of the hernia of the gut
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This is called the hernia of the gut, and it is a large swelling, according to the colour of the body: and it is very common among women
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	It is of two kinds: either it is natural: or it is accidental
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural kind there is no wisdom.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental kind is of two kinds: one of which is like a swelling of fat knots
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other kind is like a swelling which comes from the bursting of an artery
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it is not right to presume that it is only with the knife, except in the case of the heel: and you must prove it, and examine it with the introducer.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find the thing like a knot of fat, and it is not suspended with any of the veins: then dry it up like knots are dried up: and draw it out with that which contains it from the cyst, if there is one in the cyst: or if not, then examine all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with that which is necessary for the cure, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Regarding the excision of things which are like knots.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.</start_of_turn>
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already mentioned all their kinds in their discussion: and it is necessary to say here the difference between a knot and an excision: in case of doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, therefore, that when an excision has heat, fever, and pain which are unbearable, until the boiling point of superfluousness is settled and corruption is completed: then the fever and heat will cease
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When there is no heat, fever, or pain with a knot, and it is contained in a cyst which is its own sac, which is according to the color of the body: and it is like cicer, and makes like a batrachia, and is greater and less.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds: either fat or containing moisture
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I mentioned in the discussion
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary, therefore, when you come to the treatment of the knot, to experience it, and to inquire about it at first with the instrument which is called Intromissum, according to the form of it which will be in the following chapter.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the way of inquiring about the heel, and all knots, is that you take this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the heel: and you gradually draw out your fingers with that until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then lastly touch your hand according to the measure of the magnitude of the apostemate.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then extract the Intromissum, and consider that which emerges from its nest
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore it emerges moisture running, whatever its colour be: then dry it with a superficial section, as I have said concerning the other apostemata
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	If it does not emerge moisture in the nest of the Intromissum, then you know that it is fatty: dry it therefore with a section having the shape of a cross, according to this shape, as I have taught you: and suspend it with threads, and scrape off the skin from all sides with ease: and keep the fat if it remains upon it, until you have extracted it whole with the Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however it is ruptured in the bladder during the operation, and it is not possible to extract it whole, as often happens in this case: then extract it broken, until nothing remains of it from it
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if anything remains of it little or much, it returns to the Node according to much.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it incites you, and there remains little of it: then make an incision at your completion, with some corrosive powders sharp: and ligate the incision, and place above that which sits the cold apostema, and care for it with the rest of the care, until it is healed
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large Node, then tie its two lips together, and care for it with that which is contained within it
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however there be a contrary swelling painful, or not painful: then strengthen, and make an incision at the place of the wound, and let it go loose for two or three days, until the wound has decayed, and the blood-boil has rested: then return to the incision of that which remains of the Node
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Concerning the instruments outside for section and perforation.
Caput XLVI.	Concerning the instruments outside for section and perforation.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	The instruments outside are of three forms.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	The instruments outside are of three forms: a large one, a medium one, and a small one
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be of iron, with rounded ends, so that they hasten the entrance into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of those which are for experience, that is, for perforation: and one of them is called a buris, which is a perforator, and there are three forms of them
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	The instruments outside are of three forms: a large one, a medium one, and a small one
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They agree, so that they may investigate through these abscesses, and exits, and fistulas, and bubbles from what is between them and the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, tapered, smooth, like a great needle which is hammered under a shield, from citrine, or from air, or from iron, or from silver
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those which are made from citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And experience is also made of black lead, which agree so that they may pass through these fistulas, whose concavity is reflected, so that they reflect with their smoothness with those reflections
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are three forms of them once more
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For since they are of iron, they are long, medium, and short, according to the quantity of the breadth of the fistula and the tightness of it
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of needles, and there are many forms of them
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For since they are of iron, they are simple, that is, they have a single curve: and there are three forms like liquids, large, medium, and small
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	From the veins there are five kinds of caeci: there are three sorts.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	From the veins there are five sorts of caeci: there are three kinds which have two curves, and three kinds which have three curves.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the shapes of scalpels, which cut and scrape knots and abscesses: there are three kinds: for large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which make the cut are acute, other extremities are not acute: they must not be placed thus, except when a vein or nerve is to be lithotomized in the excision of knots near the fear of cutting the vein, or a nerve: and that the patient may recover quickly from the pain which he endures in the excision of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the Magdae, and there are three sorts of them.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of air, and are similar to a radio with which alcohol is made: and in their wide extremity is a hidden Spatumilis point: and in this runs inwards and outwards whenever desired, like water
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shapes of the Spatumiles which are driven between the fingers at the perforation of an abscess: and they are not perceived by the patient: and there are three sorts, large, medium, and small
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The shapes of the veins when their flow of blood is separated: and there are three sorts, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made of air, or of citrine, round, to the length of a palm, like water: and they are flexible.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these sorts of veins be large and small with you: so that you can cut the blood quickly when necessary, and then when it is not necessary for the physician to be present
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	Truly, you must not use silk in the incision of blood in every part of the body, and must not use it except in places where there is carnation: such as tears of the leg, and hip, and tears of the arms, and breasts, and belly, and groin, and similar places, from tears of carnation, humidis.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when there are other small instruments of silk of similar shape to the knuckles of fists, according to their form: with which blood is severed when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of the vein, or artery: and when there are wounds of a round shape according to this form.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Of the care of the breasts of men which are absorbed by the breasts of women.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell because of sleep (that is, when they begin to become soiled during sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and they remain after the sleep.</start_of_turn
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes this should cut across the breast with a lunar section, according to this shape from the line, to the line, and then scrape off all the fat.</start_of_turn
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then apply alum from the ointment of the incision.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast leans downwards and becomes soft because of its size, like women: then it is necessary to find in its two upper sides two similar circular sections like the moon, each of which contains the other at the ends as far as the greater line includes the smaller, according to this shape from the line, to the line, and then scrape off the skin which is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and administer what we have said about the suture and powder, which is necessary for the care, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not perform the incision which is necessary, either because of the patient's anxiety or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary to insert a sponge soaked in corrosive unguent beneath the wound and withdraw it, until that which remains of the fat has been corroded.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	And concerning the perforation of the apostematis, which occurs under the nail of the thumb.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn>
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemata which occur under the thumb are of the kind of hard strophe, which contains vesicles, and from these are the things which contain humors.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And these things which are from the humors which contain moisture, it is necessary to cut with a lunar section, in the manner of this figure, from the line b to the line g, as when all that is in the apostemata from the marrow is evacuated, then insert a sponge soaked in corrosive unguent beneath the wound and withdraw it until that which remains of the fat has been corroded
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the piece of bone, and care for it with a suitable unguent until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the apostema were of the kind of nodules of the strophe, then cut through the top of it, as we said concerning the strophe which is equal in size.</start_of_turn>
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, a wound has extended in this way as to emit pus, then apply cautery to it, as we said above.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	And concerning the incision of the apostemata which occurs because of the artery and the vein.</start_of_turn
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.</start_of_turn
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is torn and the skin above the wound is consolidated, then many times a wound occurs from the apostema: and in the same way a wound occurs in the vein also, as in these aposmata and swelling.</start_of_turn
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs which show that swelling and elevation are caused by an artery and a vein are: because when swelling is caused by an artery, it is long, aggregated in the depth of the body: and when you press the swelling with your fingers, you feel as though there is a stridor.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is caused by a vein is rounded in the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the incision above this swelling is an error, especially if it is under the armpits, and the groin, and the nape of the neck, and in many parts of the body: and it is great danger.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is necessary therefore that its care be taken with fire, and that from iron also in the limbs, or in the head, care must be taken
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Because of that which is from iron is from the swelling of the orifice of the artery, find in the cut in the length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the cut with hooks, afterwards the artery: and loosen the swelling from the tunics until it is detached.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce under these the needles, and make the swelling penetrate up to the other side, and ligate the artery with a double thread in two places, according to what you were taught in the extraction of two arteries which are in the times
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then tie the place which is between the two ligatures with a sponge, until the blood which is in it has gone out, and the swelling is dissolved
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then give treatment which generates pus, until the ligatures fall away: afterwards care for this with suitable unguents until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it should be swelling because of the cutting of a vein, then you must hold your hand as much as you can from the swelling with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the needle under the place where you have held your hand, and make it penetrate: and there be in it a doubled thread, until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with the thread itself the surrounding tissue: according to what I have told you concerning the thread of the vein, from two parts with two extremities of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If, however, you are about to draw out the thread, then insert the needle again with another thread under the whole surrounding tissue at the incision of the needle: first, and then draw tight your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the surrounding tissue in its middle, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut away the excess of the skin, and let go what is bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it a little powder which you have submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment, which is done with poultices and unguents, until healing takes place.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	And concerning a wound caused by the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	(The remainder of the text is not included in the request, so I cannot provide a translation for it.)
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Like that which happens with a wound in an artery and a vein, in the same way happens a wound in nerves: which happens in a violent percussion, or happens from excessive labor, and similar things: and it is most common in the armpits, or the calves, and in every place in which there are joints: and it is a serious wound.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It is like the color of the rest of the body, and is in various dispositions without pain: and when it is squeezed with force, feels in it a weakness similar to fainting
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not a wound gathered in the depth of the body, but is under the skin, and it is moved to every part, and does not go forward, or backward, or to the sides
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	That which is in the joints from the bones should not be pierced with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps thereby a contraction will happen.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	However concerning that which is in the head or in the face, find the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If there is a small swelling, then hold it with forceps and cut it off from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a thread and scrape it off: then take it away and join it with a suture: and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the cutting away of a swelling that happens between the bones.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It often happens to many people in the depths of their bodies, and in the rest of their bodies, a swelling which is named Fungalia because of its likeness to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is thin and their head is large, and their lips are closed over them
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it is from a small bone: and it is from a bone which becomes large downwards
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself once saw a man, and in his belly were two swellings which were greater than any other like mushrooms: there was no difference between them, white or black, as regards the root, and they were closed over their lips, and they were found to be soft and moisture always ran from the bone.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I cut them away, and I found in one almost eighteen ounces and in the other almost six ounces. And the operation in their incision is like this: if the patient is moist and the colour of the swelling is white, moist and thin of root: then cut it with a wide spatula and be quick about it.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Many blood vessels are expelled from the vicinity of its section: be careful therefore if blood incites you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a sickly and timid patient from an incision with iron, then take lead from leaden thread made into a loop, and tighten it with this: its method is as we have said, and let it go in two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the tightening.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease tightening the lead until it is broken, and it falls away without toil.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If, however, the vessel be large of the root, then in its incision there is something fearful and small: especially that which is within
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	It is possible indeed that you cut through its middle
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it, until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you cut through a vessel which is of a dusky colour, little sense, and bad aspect: for that is a cancerous swelling: and I will remind you of cancer after this
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Of the care of the great Vmbiliculus.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The great Vmbiliculus swells from many ulcers.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from rents in the bowels which are above the belly: and comes out from them either blood vessels or intestine, according as happens in the rest of the ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, as has been said before
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a clotted mass in that place
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it is because of a wound of the scrotum, and the exit of the testicle: then the colour of the swelling is similar to that of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the discharge of the intestine, then its place is as we have mentioned, with an increase in various places.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you touch it with your finger, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and causes great pain.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If, however, it is because of humidity, it is soft: then it is not hidden when you touch it with your hand, neither does it constrict, nor does it swell.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is because of blood, then it appears like a black mole on the scrotum
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If it is because of a dead animal: then the swelling is great, thick, hard, and is formed according to the quantity of one
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is because of wind, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the treatment for this is as you consider, if the swelling of the navel is because of a vein or an artery or the wind: then it is necessary to abstain from its treatment
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in this there is fear and danger, as it was taught you in the chapter where I said that swellings caused by an artery or a vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the swelling of the navel is because of the intestine or the spleen: then it is necessary to expel the patient, as long as he holds his breath, and to keep him standing extended
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with a cauter in the circumference of the whole navel
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Afterwards command him to rest his head between your hands over his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Afterwards encircle with a broad bandage the circumference of the belly around the place where you have cauterized.</start_of_turn>
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards extend the middle of the belly towards the upper parts with a large hook.</start_of_turn>
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Afterwards bind him firmly around with thread or silk cord: and make a knot that will not slip.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Afterwards open the extended middle of the belly above the ligament.</start_of_turn
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find that the intestines are caught by the ligament: then draw out the ensnared, and introduce a finger of the index into it, and press the intestine inwards towards the belly: and if you find a tumor, then grasp it with a hook, and cut off its excess.</start_of_turn
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if it is a vein or an artery: then encircle it much.</start_of_turn
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.</start_of_turn
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And grasp two needles, and introduce them through two strong threads: and introduce two needles around the circumference which you made around the belly in the manner of a cross, which you make penetrate.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the belly in four places over the needles: and if you wish, remove the needles and leave the place, until the extended flesh decays: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it off when it becomes thin and decays.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what is necessary from the unguents, until he is healed.</start_of_turn
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	And if there is a prominence of the belly from the flesh or from moisture: then it is necessary to concave the belly, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract blood, or moisture, as you find it in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for the place with that which solidifies it.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	And care for the wound
Caput LIII.	Wound care
