Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the bowstring persists until the marrow, then its strength is not prolonged
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the bowstring is not fixed except in the body of the bone and does not penetrate as far as the marrow: and remains sick for some days without any of these signs occurring: then plan for traction and extraction of the bowstring
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed at the side and does not yield to traction: then administer ointment around the bowstring as I have said before: then keep the place clean until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however the bowstring is already hidden in the body and is hidden from the sense: then inquire about it with your hands.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with some instrument that is suitable for its traction.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you cannot do more for it because of the constriction of the wound or because of the length of the bowstring in the depth: and there is neither bone nor nerve nor marrow there: then find over the bowstring until the wound is enlarged and the bowstring can be easily extracted.</start_of_turn
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If the ears be retained by the tension of the flesh, then loosen the flesh firmly from all sides, by every possible means, and with all ingenuity, unless it be possible to remove the flesh from the fracture of the ears, and to twist them until it is healed.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	When you perform the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of your hand with the forceps at all parts, until you make it evacuate: and at the last moment of evacuation, lest the arrow be broken, and that it be difficult for you to draw it, and for its own extraction
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If it is not possible to remove it in an hour, then leave it for a few days, until the surrounding parts become putrefied.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then do it again: if indeed it opposes the flow of blood, then administer what we have said concerning the cure in its chapter: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer all possible ingenuity in order to remove the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowly, and firmly, as I have said
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	It is necessary that you do as you pull out the arrow, so that the wounded person is in accordance with the figure, as it is in the case of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	How much is good enough.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the figure.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which goes out from the contrary side, or which proceeds from something to the exterior: or it causes a swelling of the extremity of the arrow by the sense of the upper part of the skin close to it, and it dries up: dry therefore the above-mentioned area, and make the incision according to the quantity which they grasp in their forceps
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it towards you: for it itself becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the circumference, until you impress the Arrow in the bone, and expand it for itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	If not: leave it for a few days: then try it again, until it comes out naturally
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the Arrow of the Bone is in it, then drive it through with that itself
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the Bone-Arrow has fractured, and you wish to give it support: then introduce into the wound an instrument with a concave surface, so that the concavity of the instrument fits against the head of the Arrow: then drive the Arrow through with that itself.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the Arrow is concave, then drive the Arrow through with the instrument entering into itself
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The Arrow shall go out through that itself.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the Arrow is poisonous, then it is necessary to cut away all the surrounding flesh where the poison is: if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for the wound with that which is suitable for it.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the Arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the armpit, or on the side: and it is close to what you touch with your hand, and it is possible to cut above the wound: then cut, and burn away from the bone or nerve, and draw out the Arrow
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then bandage the wound, if necessary, and care for it until it heals
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of Forceps with which Arrows are drawn out.</start_of_turn>
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the Arrow, they do not slip from it.</start_of_turn>
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	There are many kinds of wounds, large, small, medium, according to the quantity of the magnitude of the arrow, and the density of its substance, and the width of the wound, and the constriction of its edges.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the wound is concave.</start_of_turn>
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the wound is blunt.</start_of_turn
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is like the extremity of a radius, so that the entrance of the arrow into the concave sagitta is alleviated, and is driven with it.</start_of_turn>
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this wound is concave like the wing of a bird: so that the entrance of the arrow into itself and its driving force is alleviated.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	About the phlebotomy of veins.</start_of_turn
Caput XCVII.	Chapter XCII.</start_of_turn>
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are usually phlebotomized in the body are thirty in number.</start_of_turn
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, there are six in the head: two pulse veins, which are behind the ears, two Herbae veins: two arteries which appear in two temporal regions: and two veins which are in the two lachrymal ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.</start_of_turn
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi veins, which are in the neck.</start_of_turn
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.</start_of_turn
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.</start_of_turn
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.</start_of_turn
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins which are cut in the arms are five in every arm
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it is on the side of the collarbone: and it is called the great vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Espalata.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the branches of the Basilic vein and the Cephalic vein: and it is called the great vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic vein, and it is placed on the side of the abdomen: and it is also called the Pallicis.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is called the vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Brachial vein, and it is placed over the elbow: and it is that from which the blood is drawn, and that which appears above the thumb when pressure is applied.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Lesser Scalene vein: and it is the vein which is between the collarbone and the mandible: and there are two branches to it
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the little finger at the bend from the side of the collarbone.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the other is the Saphenous vein: and its place is beside the heel from the side of the abdomen
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the Popliteal vein: and its place is beside the heel from the side of the collarbone
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins similar to these
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	As for the bleeding of the two veins after the Aures.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bleeding of these two veins after the Aures is useful for treating ancient cataracts, headache, haemorrhoids, and head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And what is the quality of a bloodletting according to what I have said?
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is that the head of the patient should be raised: and the occiput of him should be scratched in the place of two veins with rough cloth in good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient should be made to strain his neck until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are behind the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek therefore what is easy for your finger, and where you feel the pulse of them under your finger, there are the signs with burnishing
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the bloodletting knife, which is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the pith, until the bloodletting reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and the pith towards the upper part, and cut the vein with the incision corresponding to the case
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let blood flow out as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind up the patient with bandages, and let him go, until he is healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it has been said in the beginning of the book, that the cauterization of the veins is done after their incision
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	About the bloodletting of two arteries in their seasons.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The two veins which are in two seasons of bloodletting are useful for ancient migraines: and for the swelling of the head and the excessive flow of acute humours to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of a bloodletting is easy as I have said above.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The sick man stretches out his neck very much, until two veins become evident to the sense of touch. And their pulse is shown beneath your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then the signs are as with a burn.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin above the vein to the upper parts with your index finger, and make an incision below, and draw out the blood, and lift the vein to the upper parts.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And make an incision like this in two other veins: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity you need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the patient's compression, and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put on the heel and the toes, and bind up the limb above the constriction: and let it go, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And thus remember the incisions and extractions of the veins at the beginning of the book
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	As for the vein of the front of the head after the Cephalic vein has been bled.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The true effect of bleeding the front of the head after the bleeding of the Cephalic vein is to bring about the old ailments of the face: and for headaches, and redness: and wounds and sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And its quality is like that which I have told you
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The sick man stretches out his neck with all his might, until a vein becomes evident.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Which has this shape
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point which is at the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and pierce through it with a needle, or with something else in the same way: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then solve the perforation of the patient, and tighten the ligature until healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when opened with a wide lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	It is not proper, that it be a sharp lancet at the extremity, like the rest of the lancets, but rather that it be blunt at the extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	The lancet must be passed through according to the passage of the vessel: because the bone is close: and perhaps in that it will break the lancet when it is slight
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the phlebotomy of veins in two tear-ducts
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The support of the two veins which are in the two tear-ducts of the two eyes, is for the eye from scabies and redness: and for the swelling in the eye, and the pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of them is, that it tightens the patient's neck with wit
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you stand over his head
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And do the phlebotomy according to the passage through to a small length, with a small lancet, broad, because in this place there is no flesh
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the lancet is sharp at the extremity, perhaps it will break
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let run out blood as much as is necessary to you
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put over him the foot of the bed, and tighten him up one night, and solve him.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the phlebotomy of veins of the nose
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are phlebotomized because of acute fever, and swelling of the head, and pains of the face, especially when it is ancient.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And what is the quality of his phlebotomy, that it may tighten the patient's neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take his left hand and grasp the phlebotomy below the tip, long: and fix it in the middle of the animal itself, between that which distinguishes the second nose from the upright line.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the nail does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you should keep your last hand with the phlebotomy together: and make the blood run out according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	And bind it up at night once.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The limb itself will restore itself quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins Guidegi
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	But indeed Guidegi considers phlebotomy to be useful for constriction of the chest, for the beginning of leprosy, for melancholy, for swelling and ulcers, and for wounds, that is, for herpetiform affections of the bowels
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that it may tighten the patient under both arms in his neck with a ligature: and the artificer should stand above the head of the patient, and the patient should sit upon his seat
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the phlebotomy of the vein to the length of the wide phlebotomy together.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood the quantity that you consider necessary, or according to what you wish for the necessity.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligature and tighten the two veins with the middle knot: so that the patient is not stifled.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	Leave him until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The patient must be left until morning.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Regarding the evacuation of blood from the veins, according to Alberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins, however, according to Alberich, are suitable for phlebotomy: because they afford nourishment to the cheek in the mouth, and corrupt the gums: and cause ulcers of the mouth, and cracks in the lips, and ulcers of the bowels, even those in the nose and in its vicinity
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that you must make the patient sit before you: and tighten his collar with a wit
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then loosen his lip and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side: and their indication is by the darkness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because around them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore make an incision on each of them as it lies.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If, however, you are in doubt and do not know which of them is suitable: then you must resort to the greater incision of both of them, and their manifestation
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do the two veins which are in the upper lip: and most of the time it runs in custom with them: and make an incision of two veins which are in the lower lip
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Regarding the evacuation of blood from the veins under the tongue after the cephalic phlebotomy
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	For indeed the veins which are under the tongue are suitable for phlebotomy: because the cephalic phlebotomy is for the prevention of those things which are in the throat, and the pain of the jaw, and the pains of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the bloodletting is such that the patient should sit between your hands facing the sun: and raise his tongue, and look under his tongue from one side a vein, and from the other side a vein: and the color of both should decline to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	And the bloodletting should be equal on both sides: and take hold, lest you leave your hand behind in the bloodletting.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under his hand are arteries, and perhaps blood will flow from them.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of three veins in the elbow
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	And there are three veins in the elbow which are bled in: their bleeding is customary in all men
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their bleeding is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pressing with a blunt needle: or by squeezing with oil to its thinness: or by drying with a needle, and that is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which agrees with the cutting
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there are wide and narrow species according to the width of the veins and the tightness of their form. The form of the bloodletting needle is wide like oil
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it agrees with opening wide veins, full, protruding, apparent, coarse, and those which contain thick blood, turbid
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this bloodletting is of smaller width and greater delicacy
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it agrees with the bleeding of delicate veins which contain thin yellow blood
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the bloodletting of the Basilica
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilica is one of the three veins which are bled in the bloodletting.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Since it draws blood from the ailments which are under the gut and the throat, from thence follows the chest, and the belly: and it joins the phlebotomist with the phlebotom, in order that it may cause fear, and be above the risk from that which is under it, for there is an artery below that.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If it should err, and add in the puncture of the phlebotomy, it will cause that artery to bleed, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to join the phlebotom with the phlebotom which is puncturing: rather let it be dry like Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If indeed it does not appear with an obvious sign, then it is necessary, that others do it, and change to another, or ask someone of its branch: or to phlebotom in the place of it the cubital vein
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It is itself evident, and dry with the phlebotom of Anesil, as we said before
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you wish to phlebotom yourself, then it is necessary before the pressure of the arm, so that you may reach the place, until you know the place of the pulse
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then signs over the place with the nail, afterwards the arm, and dry the area with a concave section with the phlebotom of Alnesil, as we said before.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful not to strike the percussion over the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you go, when you tighten the ligature, the inflation in the place which you signed with the nail, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: you must therefore do it thus
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	And if blood goes out at the phlebotomy like urine of a child, and it is thin, red: then you know that it is from the artery
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then proceed accordingly. Place your finger upon the said spacious area and withdraw your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is severed (which often happens), then tighten the arm and let go: and let the patient beware of its movement: and stay above its fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Do not move it for a few days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If however blood is not severed, and you suspect it: and you are not present in your moment with medical supplies, then cut the artery if necessary
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities contract and blood is severed
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the cork of a vessel and find the place: take the middle one and tighten it upon the place of the stricture with ligament and nails until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is severed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for it as before remembering the evacuation of the blood from the place of the broken blood vessels: and the clotting of blood in this is not difficult in many situations because of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of the ligament from the arm
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the cubital vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the cubital phlebotomy are said to be useful because they draw blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the branches of the basilica and the cephalic veins, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	It is convenient for the phlebotomist that there is fear of phlebotomy because under it there is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds in the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds the nerve, there occurs in this a stupor, and the healing of it is difficult, and perhaps it will not heal completely
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears to be very sensitive.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	And if it is hidden in some people, and is slight, and is not visible: then it is necessary to perform a vein-cutting as you would perform an Alnesil section, and to ligate the nerve with your own hand.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If it is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The vein of the head is to be cut because it attracts blood from the head and supplies it to the eyes
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein to make its own puncture, if you will, with a puncture like that of the olive, or like that of the myrtle: because it is safer for the veins of all than to cut an artery or a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Indeed it agrees with you concerning the puncture of the head vein, that you must ligate it only at the level of the lacerated part and that you inquire about a softer place: and it does not harm if it is not found with the first percussion, as it returns later with repeated punctures.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Indeed perhaps it is postponed in some people when it is not cut in the first percussion, but it does not harm that postponement in anything
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be observed in its practice.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and the accidents that arise from it, in whose rectification you must reflect
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, you must know that phlebotomy is not administered except for the conservation of health, and the preservation of life, and the care of ailments.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And as for the making of a phlebotomy in one of the three veins which are in the cubit, namely Cephalica, and Fusca, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And as for the making of a phlebotomy in the beginning of spring after fasting, in summer, and in autumn, and in winter after a meal, when there are signs of repletion.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	The phlebotomy shall be made on the first or third day, after three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, the phlebotomy which is given in fevers has no fixed hour: but when there is convenience and necessity for it, at night or day, at any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not permitted that phlebotomy be made of children until they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither is it permitted to make phlebotomy of a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Neither is it permitted to make phlebotomy of old people who are already past sixty years old.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone wishes to make a phlebotomy for any reason whatsoever: it is necessary that he should have previously purged his bowels with a mild laxative, if there is much stool retained in the bowels: in order that they do not attract the veins near the phlebotomy by the putrid matter of the bowels.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither is phlebotomy to be made of a patient who is suffering from acute nausea, nor of a constipated or drunken patient, until these things have been removed from the body.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither of a patient with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And caution must be taken that phlebotomy is not repeated immediately after a meal, or vomiting, or flux of the bowels, or abundance of coitus, or labor, or exercise, or wine, or eating.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Consider then the condition of the humors before this, if blood is thick with food and drink, and with the physicians: if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Consider then the bath, if it does not prohibit it: or some exercise is performed, in order to refine the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And make a phlebotomy of him in the chest, about the third of the day, as we have said: and strive that he evacuate his chest from all bad animals: such as distress, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents, such as work, and pain, and luxury, and such like things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let his food be such things as are wont to men from aromaticness, and fragrance, and pleasure and such like things, according to the quantity which is possible for him
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then sit the phlebotomist above the knee, which is higher than the knee of the phlebotomist: then extract his arm, and wipe him with the hand of the phlebotomist twice, or three times.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then bind the ligament with a bandage, and bind it twice.</start_of_turn>
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the bandage be temperate, because when the bandage is unequal, or by excess in the bandage, it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, then it hinders the course of the blood also.</start_of_turn>
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the bandage, it is necessary that the phlebotomized man wipe his hand towards his navel, until urine is expelled, and the senses are restored.</start_of_turn>
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist washes the phlebotomy with a little oil, as is proper.</start_of_turn
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his finger of his left hand on his left knee under the place where he wishes to make the phlebotomy, slightly: so that the urine does not escape, and the blow does not strike.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because from veins is as much as from intestines like a flying cord at a phlebotomy: and from solids is that which is filled with wind: and when you put a phlebotomy above the solid, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and tears the phlebotomist, and does not open the vein: and if it opens, it is strict. Because of this, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm and attentive in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	And then let go of the phlebotomy
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If indeed a vein opens from the wound of one, then that is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then do it again in that wound a little lower or a little higher with force: if the place does not swell
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	Which if it swells, or if the patient becomes pale, then leave him for a day, or two: and do not tie the ligament.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps the swelling will draw out the cold.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither put on a compress.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	And then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	Because if the opening is small, or if blood runs slowly: and be mindful that it does not escape from the blood more than is necessary: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place following the rule, and add a little to the operation
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it with force, before the place swells, for the swelling is in many people in the operation before.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If indeed you see the place swollen already, then do not repeat over it entirely, for that does not excuse you from doing something else
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put on something of the faeces of oil above it: because it will soothe the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	It is better here than pure oil and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	Similarly, apply the fat of oil to every phlebotomy you make, which you do against the course of the blood: and they will make that blood clot, and solidify, when put on one of them over the place
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes thin and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If this happens in the place of the phlebotomy after a large opening, for many do this, especially for those who are not phlebotomists except by their own fault, or who have made a small incision, then immediately apply and put over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed up: and bind it for an hour: for it will dissolve
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has been let out of the vein itself, with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything remains in the place after a few days black or yellow, it does not harm: and if it does, put over it something of aloe, or myrrh of the simples: or something of the juice of mint, that is, camomile or something similar to that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many indeed happen clots and swellings at the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand over it then, and if you find softness under your compression over it, then that is bad
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Because thus you will put over it something which we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow out of it from the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster of it with that which has styptic properties, so that the place is bound up.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself with the rest of the treatment, until you are healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	It is also necessary to remove all blood from a person according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears in the blood that is red in colour.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For blood that is black, let it go out, until it becomes red: and in the same way if it is thick: let it go out until it is thinned: and in the same way if it is acute: until its sharpness is gone
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for the full, strong, and indigent person to take only one bloodletting, in order to strengthen the one which is being taken out, and to make the phlebotomist wide: and in the one who is weak, let the contrary be done
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to take it out in veins, and that the opening should be strict: and it is better that it be administered by the cutting across of a vein, not by puncture
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safer from the flow of blood, and from cutting nerves: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by width and length
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And whoever has become faint during phlebotomy, it is necessary to give him some bread soaked in pomegranate juice before phlebotomy: or vinegar, if he is feverish: and let him take from the blood in three veins, or four
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if his complexion is pale, let him take before phlebotomy bread soaked in honey syrup, or in scented honey syrup with spices, or in scented fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If a fainting occurs during phlebotomy, and the cause of it is too much bloodletting: then it is necessary to give in the pot some water with meat, and fragrant syrup: and to mix it with aromatic herbs, and to support his chest with these things: and to do all the things which we said in the chapter on fainting in order to evacuate
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to drain his arm and stop the flow of blood should perform a phlebotomy because of the great evacuation, and his power should be mild so that he may gradually stop the blood in proportion to the amount of power used on a daily basis.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to drain his arm and stop the flow of blood should perform a phlebotomy since his power is great: let him do this after seven or nine hours of the first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body towards the side opposite to that from which he is leaning: let him do this every second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much hot and acute blood, which causes fever: let him draw from this blood in a single vessel and extract a great quantity of it: and increase the opening until syncope occurs: after he has restored all the conditions of phlebotomy, and has placed his hand over the pulse of the blood, so that there be no risk of syncope at that place
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times this happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and neglectful
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	Neither should he attempt to drain the arm and stop the flow of blood when the orifice of the vein is closed, and when the blood flow is difficult, as he may thereby cause a premature evacuation of the blood exceeding what is necessary, and causing swelling to extend quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For indeed that is bad, rather let him leave it alone until the next phlebotomy is performed
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or move with the sharpness of the phlebotomy that which has coagulated from the blood in the vein, and put upon it some dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put upon it some of the lard of pork, or rue, and compress it mildly, until the blood has drained out
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the bone has slipped down, then let it go, and do not hold it, until the slipped bone settles.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If indeed the need compels you to drain the blood secondarily, and this is not excusable, then either perform phlebotomy in the same place above the wound, or in the arm or bone elsewhere in the limb.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But as for the veins of the arm, phlebotomy must be performed at the place of the cubital fossa and the elbow, when they cannot be found, for they are hidden, because they are composed of bones.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that the patient dips his hand into warm water, until the wound turns red, and the bone reappears visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it should be bound up over the wound with a slight median constriction
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then phlebotomy should be repeated gradually across, not along, and neither in length: and let the opening be wide, and your phlebotomy should be as little as that which is done over the nail of the little finger
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If it is prohibited that the blood should escape, then repeat the dipping of the hand into warm water, and let the blood run through the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If indeed you are in the summer days, then you are excused from the repetition of dipping the hand into warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And most of all, blood is set in warm water in the wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And this bleeding of this bone is more harmless than all the other bones, because there is no pulsating vein or nerve under it
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy indeed of the right hand is equal to the treatment of the liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you bind the wrist of the hand with a ligament or your hand itself, after you have introduced the hand into the warm water, until the bone swells and the sense of cold disappears
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomy is performed across.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you make the incision completely, it will not cause him any damage in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And take care, do not move your hand with the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Beneath it there are naked nerves of the fingers from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then move the hand to warm water, and let the blood flow out of it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not move it into warm water, the blood will coagulate in the opening of the vein, and will be prohibited from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted from the blood the quantity necessary, then put upon the vein oil and salt: so that it does not harden too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way it is necessary to do with every strict limb.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The remedy for the pain of the left hand is: because it is related to the spleen's ailments: and do the same in the phlebotomy of the right hand, just as you did in the second one equally
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	As for the veins of the phlebotomy, their remedy is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as the ailments of the uterus, and retention of menstruation, and kidney disease, and ulcers of the buttocks and thighs of old age, and similar ailments
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that it allows the sick limb to enter warm water: and make over it friction, until the vein bursts: and bind above the junction of the limb with a bandage
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the veins are located at the heel, appearing under the thumb: and they are stretched out from it on the face of the foot of many limbs
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The vein is therefore to be taken in a larger branch of itself, or at the heel in its collection: for this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If the vein is taken from the face of the foot, then take care from the nerves that are under it over the face of the foot
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your vein which you take from the transverse [artery], as though you wish to cut through it: and let the vein be strong.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the blood is prohibited from coming out, then wet the foot of it in warm water: and let the blood run in the vein until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the phlebotomist makes a mistake in the first attempt, then he must go up with the phlebotomy to the upper part, for the place is safe, and it is not necessary to fear from there any harm, when you cut from the nerves, as we have said
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And in the same way with the other saphenous vein of the foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatica, however, the place is at the heel from the side of the Achilles.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	The cause of the pain of the ankle is because of the cold blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	The quality of the phlebotomy is that you must make a firm ball, and hurry: and bind up the leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel four fingers, with a fine thread that does not show except for that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the phlebotomy must be taken according to whatever method is possible to you, or according to the incision: and it is better to cut through the vein by incision, or by section
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place is safer, and it is hidden in many men
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If it is not to be found [in the veins] and does not appear to the sense: then let a phlebotomy be made of some limb of his, and it will appear in the heel, and will be about the auriculare: and let it be cauteryed from the nerves, and let the blood run out in the quantity which you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tight dressing, and place over the site of the phlebotomy the skin, and bind the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It will soon heal.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On the subject of bleeding, and the quality of the blood.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 153.</start_of_turn>
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	The humors are produced from the bodies, and from the air, and from the bile
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the process of bleeding takes place in two ways
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One is by scarification, and the other by extraction of blood: and the other is bleeding without scarification
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this bleeding which is without scarification is done in two ways
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.</start_of_turn>
Aut est absque igne.	Or without fire.</start_of_turn>
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the humors which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood are fourteen in number in the body.</start_of_turn>
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of these, one is the Alnocrati humor, and it is the last of the head: and the Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and the Alhagdahim humors, and there are two layers of the neck from two parts together: and the menti humor, and it is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth: and the two spatular humors: and the Alachosos humor is over the end of the tail: and the two focilium humors, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and the two crurium humors: and the two cauillarum humors.</start_of_turn
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	The wind-pressure does not extract blood from the small veins scattered throughout the flesh, and because of this it does not cause a loss of blood, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to apply the wind-pressure either with fire or without fire in any ailment which arises from excess, until the whole body has been evacuated.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity compels one to use the wind-pressure for an ailment, or by habit, we administer it at the beginning, middle, and end of every month, and whenever it is required.</start_of_turn
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For it is in men that when multiplied in blood, until they require its extraction by the wind-pressure, they find in their head their burden, and suffering.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them [the veins] is found swelling and redness in the face, head, and neck.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them is found itching in the face, forehead, and temples, and darkness and blurriness in the eyes.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them is found a wound at the site of the wind-pressure.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them is found laughter multiplied.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them is found a taste of blood in the mouth: either the tongue is scorched, and blood is spit out.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them is found sleep multiplied.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them is found vomiting blood and redness, and boils, and wounds, which are similar to these.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of these things, or if it is in the middle of the month: we order that the wind-pressure be done immediately, after two or three hours have passed.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of the Ventouse of the Neck is: because it itself contributes to gravity in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It should remain in place after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	This is the place of the Cephalic Venous Cut
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not allowed to use it on those who are of cold complexion or in whom there is catarrh
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings on great suffering.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of this it must not be used on the elderly, in whom there are cold ailments in the head
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But whoever uses it too frequently will generate over it aversion
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of this it is necessary to give the Ventouse a rest, laying the hand with the instrument away from the lower parts, fearing the generation of aversion
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Ventouse or the Alkehel is the place of the Incision of the Fuscus, and of the Incision of the Basilica, and because of this it brings on asthma, constriction of the chest, and cracking of the instrument, and coughing, and swelling
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary to apply the Ventouse of the Alkehel loosely, because if it is placed below, it will cause stiffness in the chest and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The Ventouse is also useful for headaches, ophthalmia, haemorrhoids, perforation, and toothache: it is the place of the Incision of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to command the Ventouse-handler not to advance the hand too quickly with the incision: so as not to cut the artery and cause the flow of blood to be interrupted
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The swelling under the chin causes the saliva to be thick in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar ailments which are in the mouth: and it is in the place of phlebotomy which is usually performed on two veins.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The swelling of the tonsils causes the saliva to be thick in the mouth, which results from reflux and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The swelling of the internal parts of the two cavities [pharynx] causes the vomiting of phlegm, saliva and blood, Basilica, Fuse and Cephalus: because these all draw blood from the small veins which are in the flesh, and these small veins are drawn from the other large veins until the attraction reaches the three large veins
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary, with regard to the main cause of the swelling, to limit the extent of the incision: because the place is stripped of flesh, and under it are nerves and blood vessels
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The swelling which is caused by the accumulation of air above the tonsils causes haemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	It is necessary, with regard to the main cause of the swelling, that there be great air, and that it should be pure air: because the place requires strong suction, and perhaps the fine veins will be torn: and a large incision should be made
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The swelling of the veins of the limbs diminishes gradually: because they draw blood from the whole body, and cause old pains in the buttocks, in the groin and in the thighs: they provoke menstruation, and cause swelling, and stiffness: and they are in the place of the phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and the great saphenous vein.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	They actually weaken the body very much, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The great saphenous vein is near to the two large veins of the limbs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the veins is that you should place the swollen part in the first cavity, and perform suction with a tempered degree: and do not prolong the position of the swelling, but place it quickly, and move it quickly, so that the humours may come to their place with equal speed: and do not cease doing this until the swelling has reached its place and become red, and the redness of the blood appears. Then you should scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who has a lean body, little hair, should make the incision once, not more: so as not to wound the place.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the surgeon to make the incision wide enough to facilitate the cutting, and not too deep: and to perform the suction with ease and speed, and with his own hand
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a thickness in the blood, then it is necessary to make the incision twice
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first instance, the opening is made under the thinness of the blood, and the evacuation of its excess: and in the second instance the accurate extraction of the thick blood is made
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is black and foul, then make the incision a third time: so as to achieve the end
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract the blood gradually or little by little, sufficeth for us one incision
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a lot of blood, we make several incisions
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	If we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary to make a deep incision: and the equal endpoint of the incision is the depth of the skin
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered from the oils concerning the position of the veins, and what should be avoided in the swollen part?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.
