While therefore the plaster remains attached to this, and the bone position is not altered, remove it, do not dissolve it, until the fracture has healed: or bind the fracture.</start_of_turn
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	Many times this fracture is bound in three weeks.</start_of_turn
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If in the meantime a hard swelling should occur, then manage it as we have said many times in its sedation, until that swelling is removed.</start_of_turn
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is with a wound, consider.</start_of_turn
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	For if it is separated from the bone fragment, or from the suture: then take care of it in this way, so that you join the fragment of the suture with that which coincides with it in the ablation of these from instruments.</start_of_turn
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If the opening of the wound is narrow, then enlarge it with a lancet according to the quantity of necessity.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	When you have removed the foreign body and there is nothing remaining, then enlarge the opening of the wound if it is wide: and if it is not, place over it patches which are suitable for that, and pressing them down, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	When the clamp is fractured, restore it.</start_of_turn>
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.</start_of_turn>
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	It is most frequent that the clamp fractures from the front part towards the humerus, and its fracture is made in accordance with one of three modes.</start_of_turn
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it fractures and separates into two, besides which it is accompanied by these foreign bodies: and it is easier to restore it.</start_of_turn
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or it is accompanied by bone splinters: and this is more difficult to restore.</start_of_turn
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or it is a fracture with a wound.</start_of_turn
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation in the case where the fracture is without a wound, is that you make two assistants present, one of whom holds the fractured clamp, and the other extends the limb above the part.</start_of_turn
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalise the fracture with your fingers, until it takes its natural shape, according to what is necessary: and do not leave it prominent or concave.</start_of_turn
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If it does not suffice with extension alone, then it is necessary to place under the patient's chin a sphere of lint, or a lancet: and let the size of it be according to the quantity of necessity. And extend and elevate the clamp, and cover the sphere with your hand, until the fracture is equal, according to what is necessary.</start_of_turn
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If the thumb cannot be drawn outwards from the wrist: because it has gone too deep: then it is necessary that the patient be placed upon his chest: and you put under the armpit of him the middle finger of his hand in size, and stretch his arm down, until the bone of the wrist which is in the depth has been elevated: and then straighten the fracture, and make equal the two bones of your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If, however, you feel pain from the wrist, and it is moving: then it is necessary that you find above that and draw it outwards with ease.</start_of_turn>
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If, however, it is retained in the bone, then you will make an incision in its bone with one of the saws that you have prepared for this purpose: after you have placed under the wrist the instrument which will protect the pulp.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It is like a spiral which has no cavity.</start_of_turn>
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its breadth is according to the size of the bone, and its thickness.</start_of_turn
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length is also according to what is possible for you in the operation.</start_of_turn
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it has two extremities, like wings: and one extremity is wide, and the other is narrow.</start_of_turn
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If, however, the disruption of the wound which you cut when you drew out the pain of the bone, is wide, and you secure it with a warm dressing: then you will join together the two lips of the wound with a suture.</start_of_turn
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the disruption is small, or sometimes there is a soft swelling: then you will close the wound with stitches, and with pieces of lint according to the quantity of the wound.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If the abscess is hard, then infuse oil of roses, aceto, and wine upon it and place above it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	If the abscess is without wound, and without incision, then place above the bone a plaster made of ground flour with alum or egg white
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And put a soft cushion above it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then put a sphere under its handle if it is stiff.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a sponge, which is that which the Saracens hold, which is long like a palm of the hand, or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a doubled cloth over the cushion and the plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a needle from a thin board, whose width is three fingers, and as long as that.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then pass the thread through the cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then pass the oil of roses with the needle in the place where the fracture falls and the swelling lies.<start-of-turn>
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the swelling over the fracture as if rolling it up, and pass the thread over its neck and under the healthy side and under the side that is swollen: and reduce the oil above every part, and as much as the fracture is tight, for the oil covers the fracture without uncovering the needle from the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And because of this the swelling must be squeezed every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever the ligament is softened, and the needle is to be removed, then straighten it up and bind the ligament again.<start-of-turn>
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the patient to sleep on his back, and put under his chin in the night a few small cushions so that when he wakes up his attendants may lift him up from that side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	The fracture of the wrist shall be elevated by elevation of the arm.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	The limb shall be bound to the chest: and do not loosen the ligaments, except in the place where the wound is urgent, or from a swelling, for up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the dressing, if you see the face of it toward that.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And keep it firm, and let it go, until it has healed and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And the fracture of the wrist is bound and comforted according to most in eighty days: and when it has healed in any man in less time.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	About the restoration of the fracture of the Spatula
Caput VII.	(The text continues with further instructions regarding the treatment of wrist fractures.)
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	Rarely does the Spatula break, and in its wide place: and they do not break from it except for the edges of it.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	When therefore it breaks from that place, and breaks in the middle of it, and it is not known except by touch: then try to prepare it according to the figure of the fracture.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And reduce it above the natural figure in every way of ingenuity, which is possible.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then put upon the place powder of fine flour with alum, and a soft cushion, and put upon it a piece of cloth doubled.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then put upon it a wide bandage from a thin board according to the quantity of the whole Spatula, or make it slightly wider.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If indeed under the bandage there is a concavity in any place of the Spatula, then equal it with the cushion of soft material until the bandage descends according to equality
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then tighten the ligature above with the thumb, constriction moderate, and the thumb firm, until it does not move from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	Consider the ligament every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Howsoever often the ligament is softened, tighten it again, and if it moves from its place, let the patient lie with the diseased side up.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	The spatula should be restored in twenty days, or in twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When this time has elapsed, then remove the ligature: and you will be secure.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For the bones from which the articulation is composed do not dislocate immediately, nor are they easily separated
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If, however, it proceeds from a fractured bone, and projects under the skin: then split above it, and remove it.</start_of_turn>
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do as we have said concerning the fracture of the collarbone from the softening of the after-boil, if anything arises from that.</start_of_turn>
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	(The text continues with instructions for treating a fracture of the breastbone.)
Caput VIII.	(End of text.)</start_of_turn>
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The breastbone sometimes fractures in the middle, and this is rare.</start_of_turn>
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	The extremities of it are most often fractured, and are broken by its accidents.</start_of_turn
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When it fractures in the middle, which inclines downwards, and if there is pain, difficulty in swallowing, and coughing: and perhaps vomiting of blood, and a displacement of the fractured bone which is not concealed by the sense. The restoration of it is that the patient lies on his back: and place two spatulas between his thumbs.</start_of_turn
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then first of all grasp the humerus of it, and bring the back together from two parts or from two sides with the hands: and subtilize in its equilibrium, according to every possible way and as it is convenient, until the figure of the bone returns, according to what is necessary.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place upon it a dressing and a pad, and place above it a small star from a board of thin cypress or acacia, and from lead or like substances in the flesh, after you have bound up the wound in cloth
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then subtilize in binding up the wound above the fractured bone, so that it does not move: and keep it firm with a bandage according to the extent of the wound, and bind it tightly enough
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Then consider the binding at all times, and every time it is relaxed, tighten it: and if its necessity shows itself to demand its solution at the itching, or corrosion which occurs in the place, or pain, or swelling: then rectify it, and solve the wound, and remove the dressing, and restore what has happened in the way of its treatment.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	Then reduce the dressing, if you are able to do this to the face: and bind it tightly, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	Regarding the restoration of the back when it is fractured.
Caput IX.	(The provided text does not include the content of Chapter IX, so I am unable to provide a translation for this section.)
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	You know that a fracture of the back does not happen except in large places which follow the back, and from the extremities of it from the anterior part.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And it does not happen except by chance, because they are cartilaginous
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	And its knowledge is not hidden from sense in the inquiry with the fingers
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is done in this way, that it is equal to the fracture with the fingers according to every possible way, until the figure is equal, according to what is necessary
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then plaster it on, and bind the fractured bone with a staple, if necessary.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	If the fracture of the ribs has descended inwards: then it happens to the patient that he feels severe pain and swelling, and puncture, just as it happens to him who has pleura: because the bone is pressing on the lung, and also happens to him difficulty in breathing, and coughing, and vomiting of blood: and this is a difficult cure.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And the old ones are ingenious in this with many devices: and some of them say that you should put on the patient nourishing substances that generate inflammation and swelling, so that the belly inflates, and expands, and drives out the fracture outwards
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We indeed abhor that it should be the cause of making the scab callous, if it does not happen.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	But if it does happen, then add to it in this way.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them say: put on over the swelling place, then bind it with force, and it is similar to the proportioning.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, they are afraid that it will draw out the swelling too much to the place, because of the disposition of the fracture.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And some of them say: it is necessary that the place should cooperate with the bandage which is already submerged in warm wax: and they put in between the ribs little pills until it is firm: so that there is an equal ligation when you wrap around it according to the circumference
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Then care for the patient with the cure of the pleura from food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	That if it tightens the patient excessively causing him to swell, and the bone is pressing on the lung puncturing it with pain, and we fear over the patient: then it is necessary that we split open over the place and take out the fractured rib.</start_of_turn>
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then we place above it the instrument which preserves the moisture, whose reminder precedes it: and we break the bone easily, and break it.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then we join together two lips of the wound, if it is large with a suture: and we care for it with sponges, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	If in the meantime a blood clot forms, then stop it, and pour in sponges into the wound, and place above it: and care for the patient with what is suitable for the clot.</start_of_turn>
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	Also during this time the patient rests on the side on which he sleeps, until he is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	On the restoration of fractures of the spine and the neck.</start_of_turn
Caput X.	Chapter X.</start_of_turn>
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	The bones of the neck sometimes suffer fracture, and rarely from attrition: and similarly the vertebrae of the back also.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	When this happens to anyone, and you do not know whether he is healed or not: then be still.</start_of_turn
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For indeed if you move his hand violently, and swell it, and cause him to die: and you cannot move it easily, neither extend it nor contract it: and when you do contract it with your fingers and pull it with a hook, he does not feel any pain, neither does he feel any numbness: then you know that he is not healed, and that it is mortal.</start_of_turn
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	When he moves it, and feels in it a constriction with the fingers and a puncture: then you know that the bone is soundly healed, and that the patient will be healed with care.</start_of_turn
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	When the vertebrae of the back suffer in the same way, and you do not know whether he is healed or not: then consider his feet: then if you find that they are softened, and that this happens in both hands: then when he lies down on his back, the swelling and discharge will go away without his will: and when he lies down on his belly, the discharge will go away without his will: and when he lies down on his back and wants to move, and cannot: then you know that it is mortal.</start_of_turn
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	He does not work in his care.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If he does not succeed in this, the matter is easier.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	His care of it is that which comes from this, as you will make a poultice with dry mustard and apply it over the Spondilam with only olive oil: or with some saffron or asafoetida.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	You should put some of this on every day, until the swelling has subsided: then put on one of the healing and soothing patches on the place, and tie over it with a bandage: and tell the patient to rest quietly and peacefully
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	He should not sleep over the part which is causing him pain, until he is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	If anything happens at the sawing of the bone of the knee, or if anything is separated from it: then it is necessary to remove it from the skin, and to anoint it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then join together two lips of the wound, if it is large, with a suture.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with some nourishment, from unguents, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	If indeed the heel bone is fractured, and is at the end of the heel: then it is necessary to insert the little finger of the left hand into the hole, and to alter the broken bone, as much as possible, and to reduce it by an equal measure.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then put on a bandage, and lift it up: and care for the wound with the care which has preceded, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	Of the restoration of the ankle.</start_of_turn
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.</start_of_turn>
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Rarely do the bones of Anchari fracture.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If they do break, the fracture of them is not, except for the breaking in two at the extremities: for they break along their length and bend inwards: and thereby arises the pain in the place, and the puncture: and the limb becomes stiff where it has fractured.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And the restoration of it is like extending your hand over it, until you are over the fracture in the manner of its shape
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is only at the extremities, then equal it with the fracture, according as it is prepared for you, until they are alike in shape again.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	If, however, the fracture is along its length, or if it bends inwards: then make the patient lie down upon his belly, until the restoration of the fracture is prepared for him.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When you have equalised it, put upon it a dressing: then put upon it a bandage of wood, or of skin: and bind tightly what you do not wish to slip from the fracture, or to remove the bandage
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And equal the concavity of them with that which supports it, until it bears the bandage firmly according to the equality: and command the patient to lie upon his back, or upon his side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	If, however, there should arise to him a cold swelling: then cease from its extension, and from its restoration, until the swelling has subsided: and place upon it what has subsided, according as before, then return to the restoration of it: and bind it as you think best
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	If, however, there should occur in the bone a swelling, or a break, extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	On the restoration of fractures of the surgeons.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	The aid is that which is between the armpit and the head of the spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If it is fractured, then its restoration is according to one of two methods.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	One of them is: take a flat piece of wood of medium thickness, according to this shape which follows
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And two ligatures are bound at the two extremities
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then it is suspended from a high place: and the patient sits on a seat
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then he projects his arm with the fracture over the wood, until it reaches its elbow, in which there is an attached piece of wood.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then suspend something heavy from above, so that it extends the minister to the lower parts.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then the doctor will equal the fracture with his hands at the same time, until the fracture returns, as it should
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And the other method is that the patient lies on his chest: and suspend his arm from the neck with a ligature
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then command two assistants, that one of them hold that which is above the fracture with his hands: and that the other hold the lower one, and extend each of them to their part
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if desired, so that the extension is stronger, then string under the fracture with a ligature, and above with another ligature: and extend each of them to their two parts
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If the fracture is close to the elbow, then it is necessary to put one ligature under the elbow and another under the fracture near the armpit
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And in the same way if the fracture is close to the shoulder: then it is necessary to put a ligament above the place and above the shoulder itself
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then let the fracture be equal with ease without toil, until the fracture be equal in proportion as it should be, and applied with a good application: then tighten it up, if the after-effect does not occur with a cold compress.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If indeed a warm after-effect occurs, then loosen the tightening up until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And put above it a soaked lambskin in vinegar and salt, until the after-effect is quiet: then tighten it up: and the manner of tightening is that you place a dressing over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place a new bandage over the dressing
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then join the arm to the aid, and place your hand open over your shoulder
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And put on a sheet, and tighten over the arm, so that the arm rests in the place of the bones: if it does not prevent you from anything from that, neither alter anything from you anything of the fractured bone
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	Which if at any time anything is altered from you concerning the fractured bone, then use greater and stronger pins than the others.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place between every pin a breadth of a finger: and let the length of the pins be according to the fracture with the addition of three fingers from every side
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then tighten over the pins the tightening as I said at the beginning of the chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And let your tightening be more strict in the place of the fracture
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And the more the fracture is prolonged, the less should the tightening be
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If therefore you have placed the pins and the tightening as we have said, when you restore the limb immediately, then do so: and if at any time a warm after-effect occurs, then loosen the tightening and the pins until the seventh day, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Consider the ligament in every three days, that it does not become inflamed in the place of itching, or swelling, or that it impede the passage of food to the limb, because of the arrangement of excessive tension.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Act accordingly in this matter, as we have said before
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	If you are certain that nothing harmful will result from it, then do not divide the ligament except after three days, or more
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	Let the patient rest on his back, with his hand on his stomach: and place under his support a cushion filled equally with wool.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	Consider at all times of the night or day, that the limb is not fractured, or the ligament is not loosened
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Act accordingly in this matter with your will
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	Place food for the patient according to the order we have given: let the food be soft at first, until the bone begins to mend: then it must be given that he gradually increases his food intake
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	In the habit of the attendants and the limb, it is necessary to bind in forty days: then it must be loosened, and a bath must be administered, and remedies must be used which restore it
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture had been open and dirty: do not divide the ligament and the bones until fifty days have elapsed, and until two months have passed
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	On the restoration of the fracture of the arm
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones, which are named the two radii
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	One of them is the forearm: and that which follows the thumb
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And another is great, which is that which is placed under a small one from the lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps therefore the larger bone breaks only, or the small: and perhaps they break together.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When therefore the small bone above breaks, then its restoration is easy, and its healing is more convenient
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the lower bone breaks, its fracture is bad, and its healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when two bones break together.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If therefore the bone which breaks is a small one above, then the doctor will agree concerning its restoration, that he put the projection of the small bone with ease, until it is equal to it.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If however the large bone is that which is broken: then it is necessary to put on a stronger bandage above all
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And it is necessary to put the hand in its natural position during its restoration, and the hand's extension beyond the knuckles
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be above the others, and let the lower articulation be over all the fingers, or over the rest: and the patient should sit with his buttocks square on himself, and let the knuckles face towards him, or be in a straight line, in height, so that the patient does not suffer any labor
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then extend the arm from the lower part, or the hand itself, or with the ligament.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And the other limb extends in the same way from above
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the doctor will equal the bones, until he has reduced them to a better figure than possible
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	And if there are any gaps in the fracture of the bone, then attempt to reduce them in their place without movement
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	If indeed it appears in that place a separate swelling which pierces the skin, and there is no hope of restoring it: then find above that and remove it according to the manner which we have said before.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	If however the fracture is with a wound, I make for that a separate incision, therefore take care of that from that point on.</start_of_turn>
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	When in the beginning of your restoration of the swelling there is a hard swelling, then draw the skin with a burnished needle with a round head, and silver, and let the middle be between the thickness and the smoothness: and tighten the skin above it tightly, until the swelling is settled: then remove the burnished needle and place a prepared dressing over it made from ground barley with albumen or oil.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then put sponges, and let the sponge which is placed over the fracture itself be wider and stronger.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And you know that the number of sponges for the arm is six in various positions: if the fracture is in one socket, or in two sockets at the same time.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then put on your bandage the stronger and firmer place over the fracture, and somewhat more with the bandage to the upper part of the fracture, or to the lower part of it: or put on a softer bandage than the previous one, according as the memory of the fracture requires at the beginning of the head.</start_of_turn
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let there be cloths which cover the fracture, soft cloths, wet: and not hard, rough.</start_of_turn
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let the thread which is used to suture be of its own kind, medium between fine and coarse, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And consider the limb and the ligament after days.</start_of_turn>
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If anything occurs whose rectification is necessary, such as itching that occurs in a limb: then it is necessary to bathe the limb with warm water until the itching subsides, and then remove the limb without constriction, until it has subsided, and then repeat the constriction.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the limb has already been relaxed, and the bone has already been removed, and similar things: then rectify the whole with your might, and consider it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	If the nourishment is hindered from reaching the limb, because of the excess of the constriction: then it is necessary to soften it somewhat, and remove it for a few days, until it has recovered, and then tighten it again
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	If indeed nothing else occurs of the kind which we mentioned, then it is not necessary to delay [treatment], except after eighty days or thereabouts
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	And then the hand of the patient is suspended at its collar
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let its collar be equal, and let its might be protected from disturbing movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And let him sleep over his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And know that this fracture is healed in thirty days, or in thirty-two days: and perhaps in eighty days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All this is according to the customs of the complexion and the might of the limb.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	Of the restoration of fractures of the limb.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that fractures of the limb, and of the fingers, are rarely found.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And they do not occur except for great attrition
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When indeed such a fracture of the limb or attrition occurs: then it is necessary to make the patient sit upright: and let him sit with his back against something equal in height
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand upon the extended limb.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then extend the fractured bone, and bring it even with the hand of the physician, until they meet in a good junction.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary to place a dressing and a bandage, if the swelling does not subside naturally
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place a bandage above according to the quantity of the place: and you have covered the limb with a linen cloth
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	If, however, the fracture is below the middle of the limb, then make it like a sphere from the cloth: and command the patient to rest, so that it may rest upon the fractured limb: then bind it with a long cloth
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the bandage be from skin, in which there is softness, so that the skin may be applied to the limb with the body of the limb: and bind it according to what is necessary
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	If, however, the fracture is outside, then it is necessary: to place a bandage above and a bandage below the limb: and let the hand be open and straight
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then place a support, as it is turned back: and extend between the fingers with the ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If, however, there is a fracture of any of the bones of the fingers, then if it is the thumb, make it even according to what is necessary
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then bind it with the limb: and if there is swelling, place upon it a straight bandage, firm: so that the fracture will be raised up and not move
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	If, however, the fracture is of the remaining fingers, such as the middle, and index, or ring, and little finger, then make it even, and bind it with the healthy finger which follows it: or bind them all according to the continuation: and that is better
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Place above it the star that is adjacent to the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	Consider also in the restoration the after-effect of the calid apostematis: and place against it what is appropriate, according to what is repeated about it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	On the restoration of a fracture of the thigh bone.</start_of_turn>
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.</start_of_turn>
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The thigh bone is fractured in many places, and it is recognized by sense: because it turns towards the inner and outer parts.</start_of_turn
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its restoration is done in this way, that it strings up the ligament above the fracture, and another ligament below the fracture.</start_of_turn
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the invalid is returned over his face.</start_of_turn
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then extend all the ligaments around it towards their own part according to equality: and this is when the fracture is in the middle of the bone.</start_of_turn
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	If however the fracture is close to the root of the thigh bone, then let the ligament be towards the part of the hip, so that the extension may go upwards: and another ligament below the fracture.</start_of_turn
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And thus in the same way if the fracture is close to the knee, then let the ligament be close to the knee, so that the extension may be towards the lower parts.</start_of_turn
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician must join the bone with his two hands, until he has reduced it according to the likeness of a natural figure: and join the bone with a good junction.</start_of_turn
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary to place a plaster and bind, if the limb is not apostematic.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	And if it happens in this way that the limb is apostematic: then leave it for a few days, until the apostem becomes soft, then return to your treatment.</start_of_turn
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	The structure of that is strict.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	The structure of that is strict.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then bind the limb until the heel reaches the root of the nail.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	Insert a long thread between thigh and limb near the knee, and draw the extremities from the upper part of both parts downwards.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then roll over the limb and thigh what remains from the other side
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then place over the thigh in the place of the fracture itself small tiles, and put upon the bone of the thigh one tile.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then put fat between the limb and the thigh with soft cloths, so as to equalize the structure.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then start from the middle over the place of the fracture with three or four bands
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the more you lengthen with the ligament from the place of the fracture, the smaller and softer and milder will be the structure
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then secure two extremities of the thread which you inserted between the thigh and limb.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Bind thus with three tiles with each of the three which are on top.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then draw up with two extremities of the thread to the bottom, until you reach the heel of the foot
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And when you have drawn up both strings also the extremities of the tiles from the other side: so that the ligament does not slip from its place.<start-of-turn>
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then release the bandage over that, while it remains, so that no fracture of the limb, neither swelling, nor inflation, nor anything of the like occurs.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	Which if anything should happen from that.<start-of-turn>
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Properly then, with the resolution of the matter, and rectify that which happened from the whole, according to what we have often said.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	If indeed there is a projection from the bone which is causing pain: then it must be made equal, if this is at all possible.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, find over that [area] and remove that: and take care of it with the thing which preceded it until it is healed
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And when this fracture of the thigh is stretched out, besides what is added to it, such as we have often said in the thigh and the arm
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	But truly in the restoration of its healing, no lameness occurs to the cripple
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if only it is restored, besides what is applied to the other leg, then it is necessary that he limp on the one which is lame from the very beginning
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And you know, that the thigh is stretched out in fifty days, or is somewhat added to, or somewhat diminished: all this is according to the diversity of complexion and the remaining conditions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	(The text continues with a discussion of treating a fracture of the knee.)
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	You know that a fracture of the knee is rarely occurs, but that it often happens that there is a great attrition on it.</start_of_turn>
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	If indeed it happens that there is a fracture, then it is not without fissure or hole in its parts.</start_of_turn
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And it is like a wound, and without a wound.</start_of_turn
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And it remains over that whole thing with sense.</start_of_turn
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And its restoration is in this way, that it is made equal what has been disrupted from its parts with the digits, until it is brought together again, and joined according to what is possible from the equality and the facility, and the making of it.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then place a dressing of ground sesame seed or barley with albumin or oil: and place above it a round sponge, if necessary: and tighten the surrounding structure accordingly.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Consider all the positions which we have mentioned in the other fractures: thus as the blunt fracture and the similar: thus, so as to oppose every accident with what is suitable for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	On the restoration of a fractured limb.</start_of_turn>
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	You know that the shin bone is composed of two bones, of which one is thick and is called the Cruris: and the other is thin and is called the Focile.</start_of_turn
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	And it happens with both kinds of fracture which happen to two bones of the forearm: and because of this, its restoration is like that of the forearm, equally, and the operation is one.</start_of_turn
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If two bones are fractured together, the shin bone is twisted in all directions.</start_of_turn
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if the thin bone is fractured, the shin bone is twisted towards the anterior part.</start_of_turn
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if the thick bone is fractured, it is found below: and it is from this that the bone is not seen.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then administer extension, and equalization, and ligation of the sponges according to this equally.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	But it is necessary to know that if the fracture of the shin bone is a severe fracture with many splinters: so that the extension is less severe, and the alleviation is gentler.</start_of_turn
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the shin bone there is something which is done more than in the forearm: and it is that when you have equaled the sponges, and have completed all your operation, then take two strips of pine wood which are administered in the making of sandals which are placed under the boards: and they are made from the nails of the palm: and choose from those which have a small thickness, and that they are not from the smallest: and let their length be according to the length of the shin bone from the knee downwards.</start_of_turn>
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then insert two sutures on either side of the wound according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	Insert one part of the crutch from one side, and the other from the other side: and they should be from the knee down to the foot
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then ligate two bands in three places from two extremities and the middle
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	When the limb is tightly bound, the knee bends to the right and left, and rests comfortably in a stable position
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And indeed it is administered a cushion of wood according to the length of the limb, and it is placed on the knee, so as to support it from movement
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And it is most important to do this in a fractured limb when the bone itself is fractured
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then consider the knee every day, and study it with the last from the apostemate, or swelling, or anything else
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If anything happens with them, then oppose it with that which is appropriate, until it is healed, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	Of fractures of the bones of the foot and fingers
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.</start_of_turn>
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	The heel does not usually fracture completely.</start_of_turn>
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	The bones of the foot sometimes fracture when the fracture is great, and the fingers also sometimes fracture: and it does not happen except when there is impact in many positions.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	If the bones of the foot fracture, and you wish to elevate them above the level of the heart, then place the patient's foot on the prepared earth, as when walking.</start_of_turn
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand, and place your foot on that which is being elevated from those bones: afterwards press, or support, the heel: and keep it even, until it returns to its place.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then place the plaster on, and support it from above: and place under the foot a board that has two flat heads.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind the plaster securely to the foot, after you have wrapped it with bandages, and left whatever else is necessary.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When three or four days have passed, then loosen the ligament.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For if the bone is equal, whether it is fractured or dislocated, you will find it to be even
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The operation is like that of wounds
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	If any of the fingers are fractured, then restore them, and make them equal as I have said in the restoration of the fingers of the hand
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place under the foot a board that is as long as the finger, and which is wider than the width of the finger: then place under the foot the board that I have mentioned above, and bind it securely
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	If the fracture is from bones, two, or three, or more, then place over every finger a bandage of its own quantity, which is bound up in linen: and bind the board under the foot: and let one head of the board rest outside the foot, so that it may hold the retention of the good one.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And remember, that you must consider all that I have said to you concerning the other fractures from accidents which I have mentioned: and oppose every accident with what is appropriate
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	About the fracture of the Vulva of a woman, and the bone of the thigh, and the swelling of a man.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When the Vulva of a woman is fractured, then make her sit in a square position.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then incline the hand towards the part of the back towards its companion, and keep it firm behind.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then let the hand grasp the fold of the skin over the hip, until the hand grasps: and let it be like a sphere from this point on
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then press the woman, and lift the back gradually
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	This is how the hip joint comes out, until it reaches before the opening of the Vulva like a sphere, and the fractured bone returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a cushion over the back of it
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When he wishes to leave, remove the hip with ease, then mix: and reduce it according to the way in which you put it in at first: then go back to your cushion first
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Make it rest for seven days, or thereabouts, and the bone will be restored
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if necessary, take hold of the testicles or the testicles themselves, and bind over the opening of the vulva a cord of reed, and introduce the testicles completely into the Vulva.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow air through the cord with force, until the testicles are inflated inside the Vulva, the fracture will return
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then let it rest with the hand, and keep it for a few days, as we have said, until it is healed
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the bone of the breast of a man or woman is fractured, then manage its restoration, and make it equal to this which we have said concerning the bone of the elbow
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And do not cover the rectum in its nearby fractures, which are of little consequence, especially for one who has something to learn, or for a layman
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book well, for in many cases the fracture itself signifies to you in many ways the straightness of its restoration and its structure: understand therefore
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	When the gut is fractured in the Virga, grasp the edge of the wound and insert the instrument into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place upon it an external dressing of cloth, and it shall be bound, and it shall be left for three days, or somewhat more, and it shall heal, if God wills it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	As for the restoration of fractures of bones, when there is associated with a wound.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.</start_of_turn>
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is fitting for him upon whom it has happened that a fracture is associated with a wound, especially if it is great, such as the femur or the tibia, or like that, immediately to perform a phlebotomy: if you testify that these conditions are present for the phlebotomy.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	And if blood flows from the wound, then it is necessary to prepare for its excision, so that it is powdered over with dry earth: if there is nothing else present.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the fracture on that same day: and do not postpone it, if there is no aftereffect.</start_of_turn
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed there should arise a cold aftereffect, then defer the restoration until the ninth day, until the aftereffect has subsided.</start_of_turn
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach him in the third and fourth days, for you will make him suffer bad accidents.</start_of_turn>
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	If however the fractured bone is prominent above the skin detected: then it is necessary to prepare to reduce it, and to equalize it with your hands with ease and small extension.</start_of_turn
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If indeed it is not prepared for extension of the limb, and its equalization with your hands: then reduce it with this instrument.</start_of_turn
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	It is an instrument made of iron, its length being equal to seven fingers or eight: and its width according to the quantity of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And therefore the physician must take three or four from these according to the quantity which is needed for the care of every kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And let it be round: and let its size be small, so that it does not double up under compression in the hour of operation: and let the edges be acute at the extremities, which have a margin at their extremities.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And let the upper be from the middle down to the lower part of it
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	It must be used in the operation, so that the acute edge of its curvature be placed over the prominence of the bone: and press it with it until the bone returns and is equal to the square of the equation.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	So strive to make the extremities of the fracture even with each other
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If its extremities are slightly fractured and do not hold the instrument well, then it is possible to cut off the extremity of the bone so that the instrument may have power
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	If indeed we cannot reduce them as we have said before, then cut them off with the knife which we mentioned before: or saw them off with a saw in any possible way
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then remain on the bone only the asperities and small cortices.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When the bone is thus reduced, and when after its reduction it finds itself painful and swollen, then you know that the bone has not returned to its natural place
Fac ergo illud.	Do this thing.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	You provide great comfort to the patient, when the restoration is completed as you do the bone.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then immerse the bandage in strong vinegar, black.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And properly if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place upon the wound fat, nor anything containing oil: lest it should cause the wound to become infected and corrupted.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then give the patient urine in an hour when the restoration of the bone is completed
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And discharge the wound clean: thus, you will cut through the edges of the wound according to the quantity of the wound
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And take heed of all precautions, lest you tighten the wound with the fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	Many indeed have done this with regard to their patients: and they have caused them to suffer either death, or corruption, or damage, that is, injury
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And be your treatment gentle, lenient, diverse in the strictures of the remaining fractures
